intro: Tricholepidium subnudum, commonly known as the naked-leaved thistle, is a flowering plant belonging to the Asteraceae family. It is characterized by its spiny, woolly stems and reduced leaves that often appear almost leafless, giving it its common name. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in a composite head, typical of the daisy family. It is native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in well-drained soils. Tricholepidium subnudum is often found in rocky or sandy habitats and is adapted to withstand drought conditions.
